8BADEEC5B61C4B4AAF66BE5D3434E9DE.description: Develop and/or revise personal and career goals based on the work placement experience.

6278521A36884C71BA3F67605567088C.description: Prepare a letter, note, card or other communication for the work placement employer, expressing appreciation.

837C54445FB4413193B97CA1955BEAC8.description: Update personal career documentation (e.g., resume, portfolio) following the work placement.

C7C018E0189049049F621F65C492BC68.description: Reflect on the attainment of personal and learning goals.

9B86C5BA15BF400980BF0C3D0CC2C3B2.description: Showcase one’s skills and abilities demonstrated during the work placement using artifacts, evidence of skill development and personal reflections on aspects of the work experience such as: hours worked; responsibilities and tasks performed; the importance of attitude towards work and taking responsibility for what needs to be done; details about the entry level wage, salary scales and earning potential; worker rights and responsibilities and the role of the union, if applicable; ownership structure (e.g., corporation, franchise, sole proprietorship, partnership); and, opportunities for advancement at the workplace and elsewhere in the industry

29E94697008A40E1B5D89A822CAAE6FE.description: Relate one’s work placement experience to personal and career goals.

5E9476F2856049F188897F2BEF3576EE.description: Document knowledge and awareness of employment standards, safety, workplace ethics, rights and responsibilities, occupational health and safety, and networking observed during the work placement.

2CACAB6224B74EDE96A187005949669D.description: Document one’s experience using electronic and other tools (e.g., vlogs, blogs, log sheets, reflective journals) to summarize and reflect upon items such as: hours of work including breaks; responsibilities and tasks performed; interactions with the employer, staff, customers and others; company or organization’s ‘raison d’être;’ and, skills developed and demonstrated during the work placement that enhance one’s employability.

D64F574153C84B1FA752AD3BF153DC98.description: Apply relevant skills and abilities during the work placement experience.

41DC72C297E242259A6F43EA04045D9C.description: Participate in a work placement experience.

A9450AD94F804E17952D7FE6406FB499.description: Reflect upon one’s performance during the interview.

7CE8FF8326124F4CB96FA398ADDB97A2.description: Participate in an interview with the employer prior to beginning the work placement.

37C706AE57B245AB981693B78F852023.description: Develop a list of questions that could potentially be asked by the employer/work placement in an interview situation as well as answers to the questions.

F7B44C601BF3427AB168B2458CFC8B9C.description: Brainstorm a list of questions to ask the employer before beginning the work placement; these may include: What is my schedule of work hours?, Who is my supervisor?, What should I wear?, When will I be provided with safety training?, What potential hazards might I encounter in the work placement?, Where do I find fire extinguishers, first aid kits and emergency assistance?, What type of safety gear am I expected to wear? Is it provided?, What should I do if I get injured or have an accident in the workplace?, How can I contact my health and safety committee or representative?, Are there any health and safety procedures I should follow?, Who is the first aid person?, Where are safety notices posted?, What should I do in case of a fire or emergency?

DEC2280E5F524820A2F4B2803CE42AF1.description: Compile an employer information package that includes documents needed for the work placement (e.g., personal career documentation such as a resume or portfolio, permission forms, logs, self- and employer evaluation forms).

3DA6D5E269B142B89540F0BF543F771C.description: Develop a procedural guide for the work placement that includes items such as: transportation to and from the work placement; hours of work; guidelines for absence and tardiness; dress code; job description; and, conflict resolution

EF9C4F5053BC43D4858DC32B20183863.description: In collaboration with all partners, develop personal and learning goals for the work placement

D10E90A2FB9E45BCAB0AB77F50CFC458.description: Research the business/organization to become familiar with its operations

6D1540406E054E61A65C05BC5FB3370C.description: Explain the roles and responsibilities of each partner (e.g., student, parent, teacher or other school staff, employer) involved in the work placement.

5AFCBA3924884E8C884445DB07647E3A.description: Describe and reflect on the three basic rights that all workers have under Part III – Occupational Health and Safety in The Saskatchewan Employment Act, 2019: the right to know – the hazards at work and how to control them; the right to participate – in finding and controlling workplace hazards; and, the right to refuse – work that you believe is unusually dangerous

29B328283D3244259C57CF472E781225.description: Demonstrate the making of an open and a closed bed.

E32C45A75AA140B28115FC75C3318ECF.description: Describe the differences between open (i.e., shortly before the bed is to be occupied), closed (i.e., expected to be unoccupied for several hours or days) and occupied beds (i.e., a bed being made while the patient is in the bed).

83A82E30C14C4DC79CCDF86C97397D01.description: Describe safety measures for bed making.

6C9BBF58CE5C4E34B9F927D1671466E0.description: Recognize the different types of incontinence pads (e.g., reusable, disposable).

D7A967605ADB4648B6552F42F42C216D.description: List the types of bedlinens used when making a client’s bed.

ECC3D46A8E344D699FDA7CDC0C589BAA.description: Explain how to handle linen according to the rules of standard practise (e.g., frequency of changes, order of application to bed, manipulation of the linen).

904011E06AE144309C86260C5E6182E5.description: Identify appropriate clothing and accessories to wear in order to maintain personal safety.

32E98DBBF09E4D2D85FD271268B7816E.description: Describe measures to ensure personal safety when at work in a health care environment (e.g., when lifting clients, when entering a client’s home, when getting to work)

96702473421A47C0957CFFD70FE69F44.description: Explain the protocol to dispose of contaminated items or waste, including sharp objects.

D1F7B462F445410AAA44DCD8E35B070A.description: List the steps to reporting a workplace injury.

A683A6B2A8214970B4B02CC8F697387B.description: Explain household management safety, including guidelines for dealing with pest infestations, linen and light housekeeping.

F1D4957F670D4C3BBE81994FE3CD0245.description: Describe safety guidelines to follow when using electrical equipment such as hair dryers, curling irons and electric razors with clients in health care environments.

0252F5D06D764E03A3ED2890D7433838.description: Describe guidelines to follow for emergency preparedness

237703CF82C041FFADEBCA3D72C4DCF6.description: Describe what to do during a fire in a health care environment (e.g., never use an elevator, cover the client with a blanket) or in a personal home (e.g., establish a muster point, check fire alarms).

391ED04A13E74E39952D7A043548232D.description: Investigate health care codes that support safety (e.g., code red, blue, burgundy, white).

1636823AB9474CD4859F7FCB63AA375E.description: Describe emergency care procedures for burns.

192ED1CD14D5430FA4B0EB2F056B2927.description: Identify factors that increase the risk of falls among older adults

1AA7A6BDE08D479880488F5829929F1C.description: Identify the safety measures to prevent falls, poisoning, suffocation and burns in older adults

7125F399685E481EBE2C58F189B0858A.description: Describe how the proper use of specialized equipment can promote client safety (e.g., call bells, bed rails, hand rails).

74275C3798004F9CB5FF83C767993063.description: List the risk factors for incidents (e.g., distracted or fatigued caregivers, clients with vision, hearing or mobility challenges, medication, age).

F603616A8A824531B82FC7802ECBE89A.description: Research the function of Occupational Health and Safety (OHS) committees in Saskatchewan.

DCA59FCC17D742CE97D735122F9673CA.description: Investigate a worker’s duties under the Workplace Hazardous Materials Information System (WHMIS).

CBEE987E5907490B96D9C49FE16AED66.description: Examine safety measures and procedures in health care environments.

973B82FE0D6747DC97DADB8065CB9EFC.description: Safety Measures and Procedures in Health Care (Core for Health Care Focus)

850A03367E29460DA609AF07A588688B.description: Examine safe practices for caregivers providing personal hygiene services.

AAF6FEFC6EC049A69EAD52663D84D625.description: Identify the safety precautions for clients taking tub baths or showers.

4D909E0E776C4C9D9E687A4DDE6B9659.description: Describe compassionate caring for the client receiving assistance with bathing.

7FB41F6F2D884953A863F061DF4701B1.description: Describe the guidelines for bathing (e.g., collect all needed items before the bath, provide for privacy, protect from burns and scalds).

B8E1DCAF22E244BD99D7F1521EA47B67.description: Explore the labelling process for personal items (e.g., clothing, glasses, blankets, dentures) in health care environments

A3A671F305374EA1BCB32F304154640E.description: Examine ways to support good oral health.

9AE9418D2CB34D27AFF687954CE3AC89.description: Describe oral hygiene and the observations to report to the care team.

05988C23F0D24B8E98ACB4FD78CCCA43.description: Discuss how to assist with personal hygiene while considering the client’s dignity, independence, individualized care, preferences, privacy and safety.

1812C8AF8A674F938054FC96BEAD1C9A.description: Examine daily care routines including morning care, afternoon care and evening care.

1896E84AB088487785ED5DC2D780885D.description: Explain the importance of personal hygiene for clients and care providers in health care environments.

C5777BBBFB5B45B9AFA6EF6B17C1EFC0.description: Recognize the importance of personal hygiene in health care environments

8FE1904EE1B44C2D8528EF289F10DD4B.description: Research frequent injuries (e.g., back, shoulder and psychological injuries) for health care providers related to lifts and transfers.

7F88C47DB5C745E195A82E753F77C5AC.description: Investigate programs and services that provide training for transfers, lifts, and repositioning (e.g., TLR or Transferring, Lifting and Repositioning training).

61C98554FDD743FEA192CA2448FBC49F.description: Recognize tools (e.g., fan-folded turning pad, slider sheet, transfer belt, transfer board) used to move a client safely.

8DEB700B621C439B9866A87B40CFFFA6.description: Identify positioning requirements in a care plan directive.

14AEEA3FFEE7448FBA1B2E450AF081CE.description: Demonstrate different types of bed positions (e.g., Fowlers positions, supine position, lateral position, Sim’s position, prone position, sitting position).

F1BFC1D233CD44129E5927C491B83BDF.description: Observe how to position, transfer and lift a client

AC04AD032700424F8C11105391B91462.description: Regularly visit a long-term care home or a senior’s residence and journal about the experience.

79791567ADB248DDBB7CFD1F228F6376.description: Investigate the possible linguistic needs of older persons in health care facilities.

5D077B9A36EC4DA185EAAAC3580C0336.description: Investigate ways to respect possibly traumatic lived experiences of older persons (e.g., veterans, survivors of residential schools, the Holocaust or the Great Depression.)

DDC08A4955584876B1C22EADD2E2CC3A.description: Investigate ways to acknowledge life experiences of clients (e.g., identifying previous occupation, constructing memory boxes).

03A6EC3104E24DC7AF9D0F0EEE1FEA87.description: Explain how to be sensitive to older persons from various cultures in a health care facility or in the home.

31F4C576B91D4D7686AEFDCD8650F7A0.description: Identify the physical changes that occur with aging in various body systems (e.g., musculoskeletal system, nervous system, circulatory systems).

9A0C3A978ECE46388669C3C29C6FB24E.description: Recognize the signs of depression in older persons.

0A12D4F3855243A89C2C9609D83003F3.description: Research the concept of aging in place.

1385B50FAAFD452A992480E2F680A92D.description: Identify the emotional and social changes that occur with aging (e.g., retirement, reduced income, social relationships, death of a significant other, children as caregivers).

D9D9C0685F6244BAB86F922C900C4EF6.description: Examine ways to care for older persons.

469C93A231044EC4B256DE2A82A89773.description: Discuss how to respond to a client who requests tasks that are not on the care plan.

65FC492B35A04C988C4789C9B4856F79.description: Investigate ways to care for garments and linens (e.g., removing stains, folding, ironing).

8543D535CA2E455FAF542429A4673E50.description: Demonstrate the proper use of a laundry machine.

E4E93D02D75547128D0057E2290B2A65.description: Explain the steps for cleaning bedrooms, living rooms, kitchens and bathrooms

12238C16502B4F3BA1EF4C7FE65E6265.description: Investigate how to use cleaning supplies safely (e.g., wear appropriate personal protective equipment, store products in original containers, do not mix products).

2A82C81682674C1E998FADD8C8B35DE9.description: Evaluate the quality of cleaning equipment such as rags, mops, vacuums and detergents.

359BB48BA4DC48C1A6C7CD385EFDAF11.description: Demonstrate adherence to cleaning guidelines (e.g., clear away clutter, work from higher to lower, work from far to near, work from cleanest to dirtiest).

011381B2031B47EAB43199F6118B1427.description: Review time management skills for accomplishing tasks (e.g., establish priorities, put client needs first, develop routines, prepare all necessary equipment).

0A01B606F3AA4468BAF4FF7E59E16854.description: Identify payment options for home management services (e.g., clients or provincial or territorial funding).

74ED65137F7D4100B1A859BB1AA84C7F.description: List the possible duties of an unregulated care provider in helping with home management (e.g., cleaning, doing laundry, taking care of pets, watering plants, assisting clients with their money, answering the phone, emptying garbage).

01C2947AC3224252BDD6B9671E0EB46F.description: Identify and define some common abbreviation used in health care (e.g., BM – bowel movement, Dx – diagnosis, FBS - fasting blood sugar).

78D7C83502EA42699817B5C09980C8B3.description: Interpret medical reference points including anatomical body planes, anatomical directional terms, body cavities and abdominal regions.

C5AE775DF03742F392988434C06B7CF2.description: Combine word elements to form medical terms (e.g., dys-difficult and pneabreathing become dyspnea, meaning difficulty in breathing).

897399A7BD6C4482BD052CEAAA58319B.description: Recognize the meanings of common Greek and Latin prefixes, roots and suffixes on which many medical terms are based.

C41F0F3C78B04AADA27D2CDC9A5B658A.description: Identify word parts such as prefixes, roots, suffixes

DE8A0E8AC7DB45E6B9B7C26E555DB2A5.description: Explore the contemporary meaning and historical origins of medical terminology.

41B31FE9B4B94F4D94FEC9B739A52903.description: Compare how teams function in different public and private health care environments (e.g., private personal care homes, long term care, hospital care).

768A541B63854B168C59859D8CB65576.description: Explain the unregulated care provider’s role on the health care team

49FD038136784507AE20C2732DD04DBC.description: Investigate the roles of various health care team members (e.g., registered nurse, physiotherapist, social worker, doctor, family member).

DCF5594F593C4965BD87F75D3B8F719A.description: Discuss the benefits and challenges of interprofessional health care teams.

0DF4B426D5084E828FBB797D3566D81F.description: Research how a health care team is created.

919675495BB94E828D5DEDDEA31F338E.description: Explore the roles and responsibilities of health care teams.

F9E80A30E4964167A140CC13F6394A6B.description: Investigate conflict resolution strategies for conflicts with co-workers, patients and families (e.g., arrange to speak in a neutral area, identify concerning behaviours, refrain from discussing details of discussion with other co-workers).

0C65DBF3479C40A08C225430C204B6E5.description: Explain ways to effectively communicate with clients living with dementia (e.g., minimize competing noises, speak clearly and calmly, use short sentences, use humor).

6A30DD9F7B4F408EB8A7FE22372C1378.description: Describe how to explain procedures and tasks to clients (e.g., put the client at ease, start with easy steps, give time for practise).

A868F7AAF8DD4E548D738E35A336260F.description: Demonstrate how to communicate with a client who is dissatisfied with their care (e.g., recognize the source of frustration, treat the client with respect and dignity, stay calm and professional, listen and use silence, leave for personal safety).

109E08082A4E4B4DB645839CCFF299EF.description: Examine the importance of compassion when providing care to clients with communication impairments.

A9702578A96646E39D7CDE16EE0EA5F6.description: Explore effective communication skills in health care environments.

72C6CFF4A2D54302A462A7A6A252AA89.description: Research laws and regulations that impact client’s rights in health care environments.

37B38AA5337144A295BC5A3EBB9821DE.description: Identify ways unregulated care providers can respect their clients’ rights.

C0FFDED9E9B24FD1B95ABAACB087B350.description: Investigate Patient Family Centered Care Principles in Saskatchewan (e.g., dignity and respect, information sharing, participation, collaboration).

7CFB765B597E41B097D9A6A5F7BB58F2.description: Describe client rights in Saskatchewan health care environments (e.g., the right to privacy and confidentially, the right to give or withhold consent, the right to autonomy).

A56B5D9F479A42C3A2E9DA2C98977DF4.description: Explain the basic human rights protected by the Canadian Charter of Rights and freedoms (e.g., the right to vote, the right to life, liberty and security, the right to equality before and under the law).

1F5D66BD08664450B5E3623D6FA4332D.description: Recognize clients’ rights in health care environments.

8398FDA673494507BAE9162DCE2DD2F4.description: Research challenges with Saskatchewan’s present provincial health care model (e.g., alternative care, home care, rural and remote communities, aging population).

C5F97DFF1AD548C9823740D0280D2E58.description: Explain the influence of Tommy Douglas and his Medicare model for health care in Saskatchewan.

C1011BA152D34582A7E91B8C13308116.description: Investigate the structure of the Saskatchewan Health Authority.

C684E5A0ED3C4B69A39471C06D70006D.description: Examine the provincial government responsibilities to Canada’s health care system.

FA66AF42EC8F421298699765631D3B6E.description: Investigate the structure of the provincial health care system.

F289314A179F477BABE72ECB4BC688FC.description: Discuss personal preferences of health care environments.

2A5D417E03FE4FEC96224B11951FED97.description: Determine the advantages and disadvantages of each workplace by visiting and touring different types of health care environments (e.g., special care homes, hospitals, respite care settings).

519D406A31BE4CC8950D23F0ABE4ED21.description: Identify the benefits and challenges encountered by unregulated care providers in different types of settings.

D639132784F849F39A45A6BE71BE8FCA.description: Distinguish between regulated and unregulated care providers.

0737B8628E5546E19FA06E4AB8B5BDF6.description: Research the types of environments in which unregulated care providers work in Saskatchewan, including: private personal care homes; special care homes; long term care homes; acute care; hospital care; home care; respite care; emergency respite care; and palliative care.

2FB43CD1AC9148A18A5BE6881EE7FAED.description: Compare different types of health care environments staffed by unregulated care providers.

F11C44C369924758AC1B0B11962B3A77.description: Examine opportunities for volunteering in the health care in the local community.

71ED8B82FB9D46498AB2351842F3CFDA.description: Recognize the unregulated health care provider’s role in providing home care services.

B4D2D864FCC147CF900CB073D21DD24F.description: Identify principles of client-centered care (e.g., dignity, independence, individualized care, preferences, privacy, safety).

2A58F7D0F51845C5B7EADCCE161E4B97.description: Analyze daily schedules of unregulated care providers.

DF732513B85A47A8B72B4B45609F1D8F.description: Identify the roles of unregulated care providers within the health care team.

34CD523B276746B682C886216716CB63.description: Compare the roles, responsibilities and training requirements of unregulated care providers in Saskatchewan.

43ED108D17724961A5596C49E3BC2DBF.description: Compare direct care (e.g., provide bathing and grooming services) and indirect care (e.g., order and maintain inventory) tasks required in unregulated care provider positions.

7A4517942D314F07832C7A8831846350.description: Investigate the potential earnings of unregulated care providers (e.g., private versus public health care facilities, training requirements).

ED5CB805E0954A6FB82690A30FEAC013.description: Research educational programs that formally educate unregulated care providers in Saskatchewan (e.g., Sask Polytech, Saskatoon Business College, Saskatchewan Indian Institute of Technologies).

88733A7F08934ABFBA2018189B5A8029.description: Describe reasons to work in the health care industry (e.g., personal goals, personal calling, financial goals, working conditions).

90B60A2E2AF2450AB7D4D5D4C6D280BF.description: Identify the various types of unregulated care provider careers such as: continuing care assistants (CCA); personal care assistant (PCA); home health aid (HHA); home care aid (HCA); daily living attendant; special care aid (SCA); and, care partner.

090D106C112C4E2B8B1B5328703B4F26.description: Investigate unregulated health care provider careers.

D012C65F28F04936B0AE9A9B8858A54F.description: Research local volunteering opportunities in caregiving environments in the community.

B9319AE7DCF9490888B92A2544A12CAC.description: Discuss how volunteering may contribute to future employment opportunities.

943A35CC5FD7402D90DA5E35D668A7A3.description: Identify the characteristics of an effective volunteer (e.g., respectful, on task, punctual, enthusiastic).

17A6850E6E7141A990F1A4B53D9C1D27.description: Explore how volunteers support clients or patients in health care and early learning environments

B2786A26E7CC4CB4877F14C322D24568.description: Examine the social and emotional benefits of volunteering in caregiving environments for everyone involved.

0BD631D49DA647B8B4A946238D20BD99.description: Identify reasons to volunteer (e.g., to learn more about a career, to contribute to the community, to help others).

85110D2010374F6A91CCFB4DD3AF0DBB.description: Outcomes Indicators Examine the role of volunteers in caregiving environments in the community.

20EF84985DF449F58279B6645F250382.description: Investigate ways nature is used to promote wellness in caregiving environments.

BF6BC53BAD6440B08FE9532924EBF158.description: Evaluate personal mood and stress after spending time in nature.

E1B3337AEF1D4599B81B1B5788A7AF9A.description: Discuss the benefits of images and sounds of nature in indoor environments.

6BA611C6580C458080AB2167C60F5482.description: Research opportunities to bring nature indoors

B5C6DFCEE2644F36AB2762DA4A539B99.description: Demonstrate how time spent in nature can impact personal connection to community.

1450902A30EF4C7981CF19327947C415.description: Examine how nature encourages pro-social behaviours.

F7C5E109689A4AAE8CF3D3C9BC43C04E.description: Explore the cognitive benefits of interacting with nature.

CBA7298B9AE24D4D8E910F16BDB369EA.description: Explain the link between lack of exposure to nature and depression.

D3D442FDC4C946F093D0EDCAE9A240B6.description: Investigate the impact of nature on stress and mood.

E718DDCD06E54ACCAD57754A3C7A4233.description: Evaluate how interaction with nature affects wellness in individuals.

02338F1DC74F41D69F0C69F8D39D7CD1.description: Describe stages of human growth for each age group, including: early childhood; middle childhood; late childhood; adolescence; young adulthood; middle adulthood; and, late adulthood.

2DFC98767C4944BCB0E0A265C6C2A149.description: Observe differences in development milestones between infants, toddlers preschoolers or school aged children.

670E8F4A9DF54251886A5FDEFE78C4D1.description: Investigate a variety of theories related to developmental stages of human growth and development (e.g. Piaget, Erickson).

C94EB2EFFBD94694A19CF66B5373DD14.description: Examine the physical, social-emotional, intellectual, spiritual and intellectual developmental milestones of: infants; toddlers, preschoolers; and, school-aged children.

095A30D11BBB46B48E72301707279F02.description: Identify the dimensions of development (e.g. physical, socio-emotional, spiritual and intellectual).

E1698DE39329462DA1B5B54FAA992A79.description: Identify developmental milestones and the stages of human growth.

73473F4C895F4AEBB13261567924BE23.description: Developmental Milestones and Stages of Human Growth (Core)

0CE435293EFC4D6496D64C156D2700FA.description: Discuss the uses of traditional medicines and healing practices with an Elder or Knowledge Keeper.

25521A254B2F45459D5827E095BA51E3.description: Research Canada’s First Nations, Inuit and Métis food guide.

91B520B0D5CF46A098050F73EE4FAACF.description: Research Métis, First Nations or Inuit care facilities in Saskatchewan (e.g., All Nations Healing Hospital, Round Prairie Elders’ Lodge, Sturgeon Lake First Nation Health Centre) and their approach to holistic care.

767061677F65400C883A870181DAF09E.description: Investigate the structure of First Nations and Métis families and their role in supporting health and well-being (e.g., extended family members providing critical care).

24EF020FEAD542F99D7021FECF33CBF6.description: Explore the connection between a healthy environment and individual and community health.

8D60E3EB0EF5419A985B8A6A8DC3EA06.description: Investigate ways traditional Indigenous beliefs, rituals and ceremonies can be incorporated into western health care systems (e.g., smudging, traditional medicines)

24FE07C0C8A84708B7495BA32CAE7BB7.description: Explore how Indigenous medicinal knowledge has influenced Western medicinal practices.

C032C279E7994FD5BE3F50CB1E51E910.description: Research matotisân, or the Sweat Lodge, as a traditional Indigenous method of healing.

4610316373DA473B901FC47BE68B2257.description: Compare western conceptions of health (e.g., absence of or pathology) to indigenous conceptions of health (e.g., when relationships with all things, including the land, are in balance and harmony).

292357F8B30A46CAACD3920C5ED2B8C5.description: Engage with a local First Nations or Métis Elder to talk about traditional life stages and holistic wellness.

72ECCD27203544609FC1B18A5C86FDB6.description: Describe the importance of achieving balance between the physical, emotional, mental and spiritual dimensions of being when providing care to others.

BC5254FA3AA64F13BF1789A78AC2FFFC.description: Investigate circle teachings in relation to life cycles and holistic health.

FD3044CFC012446D9590D5771641A080.description: Explore the concept of wâhkotowin (i.e., we are all related, not only to each other, but to the Earth and all things).

72A1277FF34C41EABE9B962B39C89173.description: Examine the concept of miyo pimâtisiwin (i.e., engaging with life in a manner that is full and includes learning, growing and healing or living the good life).

0773446C66684CD4A56A55A2349238FE.description: Explore the worldviews of health and well-being of Métis, First Nations and Inuit people in Canada.

FDD6D4F896764DC9B096D0B439D4C055.description: Indigenous Worldviews of Health and Well-Being (Core)

F7203A2EDC924ED58EACF7664FD48418.description: Identify laws protocols (e.g., Highly Efficient Privacy Preserving Authentication) that regulate privacy and confidentiality in caregiving  environment.
